case_name: Atic Industries Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference I.T. No. 65 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference  I.T.  No. 65 of 1966.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 809 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 16, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference I.T. No. 60 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: AND CIVIL APPEAL No. 809 OF 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 16, 1967 of the, Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference T.  No. 60 of 1966.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2086 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from Awards Part I & II dated September 27, 1967 and November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference I.T. No. 65 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: AND CIVIL APPEAL No. 2086 OF 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Awards Part I II dated September 27, 1967 and November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference  I.T.  No. 65 of 1966,.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Labour, Ahmedabad referred nine demands of Atic Industries Ltd. workmen to Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat by order dated February 19, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: As Atic Industries Ltd., and its workmen companyld number settle the various demands made by the latter, on the joint application of both, the Deputy Commissioner of Labour, Ahmedabad, by order dated February 19, 1966 referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat, nine demands made by the workmen.

facts.text: Demands referred included revision of wage scales, dearness allowance, shift allowance, vacation traveling allowance, housing facilities etc.

anchor.surface_text: The demands companyer various matters and have been elaborately set out in the Schedule annexed to the order of reference. It is enough to numbere that the demands companyered revision of wage scales, dearness allowance, shift allowance, vacation traveling allowance, housing facilities etc.

facts.text: Demand No. 4: All workmen using S.T. Bus Service to be paid Rs. 20/- per month as Bus Allowance, cyclists Rs. 15/- per month Cycle Allowance, train users Rs. 10/- per month Train Allowance.

anchor.surface_text: Demand No. 4, with which we are companycerned was as follows All workmen who make use of the, S.T. Bus Service shall be paid Rs. 20/- per month as Bus Allowance and those workmen who companye Cycling from places where S. T. Bus Service is number available shall be paid Rs. 15/per month as Cycle Allowance and also those workmen who companye by train shall be paid Rs. 10/- per month as Train Allowance.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal by Award Part I dated September 27, 1967 disposed of demands Nos. 1,2,3,6 and others; Part II dated November 15, 1967 disposed of demand No. 4 etc.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal by its Award, Part 1, dated September 27, 1967 disposed of demands Nos. 1, 2, 3, 6 and By its Award, Part 11, dated November 15, 1967, the Tribunal disposed of demand Nos. 4 5. 7 and 8.

facts.text: Tribunal directed Atic Industries Ltd. to pay 15 paise per day to every employee staying 5 miles or more from village Atul, effective January 1, 1968, not on leave days.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of demand No. 4, the Tribunal directed the Company  Atic Industries Ltd.  to pay an allowance of 15 paise per day to every employee who stays at a distance of five miles or more from village Atul. The Tribunal directed this payment to be made with effect from January 1, 1968.

facts.text: Atic Industries Ltd. filed Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 challenging the grant of transport allowance.

anchor.surface_text: Atic Industries Ltd. has filed Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 challenging the grant of this allowance to its workmen.

facts.text: Workmen filed Civil Appeal No. 2086 of 1968 challenging Award Parts I and II, restricted by SC order dated September 24, 1968 to transport allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen have filed Civil Appeal No. 2086 of, 1 968 challenging the various matters companyered by the Award Parts I and II, regarding wage scales, dearness allowance in so far as the Award was against them. ... But this Court, by its order dated September 24, 1968 has restricted the Special Leave only to the question of transport allowance.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Labour referred nine demands of Atul Products Ltd. and workmen by order dated June 30, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Here again, on the joint application of the said Company and its workmen, nine demands were referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat, by or-der dated June 30, 1966 of the Deputy Commissioner of Labour, Ahmedabad.

facts.text: Demand No. 6 for Atul Products: Company to provide free transport or pay Rs. 15/- per month till then.

anchor.surface_text: Demand No. 6 with which we are companycerned in this appeal was as follows Company shall provide free transport facility to all workmen. Till such time free transport is made available every workmen shall be paid an allowance of Rs. 151/- per month.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected free transport but directed Atul Products Ltd. to pay 15 paise per day to employees 5+ miles from Atul, effective December 1, 1967, not on leave.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of demand No. 6, the Tribunal rejected the demand regarding the Company being made to provide free transport facilities. However, the Tribunal directed the Company to pay an allowance of 15 paise Der day to every employee who stays at a distance of five miles and above from village Atul. The said payment was made effective from December 1, 1967.

facts.text: Atic Industries Ltd. and Atul Products Ltd. are public limited companies manufacturing dyes and chemicals in village Atul.

anchor.surface_text: Both Atic Industries Ltd. and Atul Products Ltd., are public limited companypanies. They manufacture dyes and chemical and other intermediates. Both the companypanies were having their factories in village Atul.

facts.text: Majority of workmen come from 5 to 10 miles away, factories not where local labour available, from distant villages or Bulsar.

anchor.surface_text: In support of its demand the Union had stated that the majority of the workmen employed in the two Companies companye from a distance of about five to ten miles. As the, factories are number situated in a place where labour force is available easily, the majority of the workmen have to companye from distant villages or the town of Bulsar.

facts.text: State Transport bus service not regular or adequate; bus fare 40 paise per trip from Bulsar to Atul, 80 paise per day.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberadequate transport reaching the site of the factories. The State Road Transport Corporation runs buses to reach the site of the factories, but the service is number regular or adequate. A workman has to incur a bus fare of 40 paise per trip from Bulsar to Atul and another 40 paise for the return journey.

facts.text: Companies opposed demands stating not their duty to provide transport, good road from Bulsar to Atul, ST bus and train available, most workmen live nearby.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Companies opposed the demands of the workmen on the ground that it is number the function or duty of an employer to provide transport facilities for its workmen to companye to their place, of work. It was further pleaded that there is a good road from Bulsar to village Atul and the State Transport Service, which was running buses on the said route was easily available to all the workmen both for companying to village Atul and also for going back home.

facts.text: Cynamid India Ltd. in same region paying 15 paise/day transport allowance to workmen 5+ miles from Atul; Tribunal increased to 37 paise for 5+, 12 paise for 3-5 miles in award published September 3, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It is seen that in respect of Cynamid India Ltd., which was in the same region, though in the pharmaceutical industry, the Tribunal had occasion to companysider a claim made by its workmen for free transport facilites or for payment of fixed transport allowance at the rate of Rs. 15/- per month. ... In this award, a companyy of which has been placed before us, it is seen that the Tribunal has rejected the claim of the workmen for directing the Company companycerned to provide free transport. But in respect of the further claim for increasing the transport allowance, the Tribunal has ultimately increased the allowance from 15 paise to 37 paise per day to every employee who was staying at a distance of five miles and- more from village Atul.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals of companies (CA 742/1968, 809/1968) and workmen (CA 2086/1968), confirmed Tribunal awards on transport allowance.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Awards of the Industrial Tribunal in respect of demand No. 4 in Civil Appeal No, 742 of 1968 and demand No. 6 in Civil Appeal No. 809 of 1968 are companyfirmed and both the appeals are dismissed. Civil Appeal No. 2086 of 1968 is also dismissed.

facts.text: Workmen must share part of transport expenses; Tribunal awarded only 15 paise/day though daily cost 80 paise.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal itself has held that the workmen must share a part of the expenses and it is on that ground that though a workmen has to incur 80 paise per day, he has been granted only 15 paise per day.
CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference  I.T.  No. 65 of 1966.
AND CIVIL APPEAL No. 809 OF 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated October 16, 1967 of the, Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference T.  No. 60 of 1966.

AND CIVIL APPEAL No. 2086 OF 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Awards Part I II dated September 27, 1967 and November 15, 1967 of the Industrial Tribunal, Gujarat in Reference  I.T.  No. 65 of 1966,

issues.text: the common question that arises for consideration in all these three appeals relates to the claim of the workmen for payment of transport allowance to enable them to go from their place of residence to the place of work

anchor.surface_text: From the facts stated above, it will be seen that the common question that arises for consideration in all these three appeals relates to the claim of the workmen for payment of transport allowance to enable them to go from their place of residence to the place of work.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction to consider the quantum of transport allowance to be paid to the workmen when once it has rejected the claim of the Union for provision of free transport

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept the contention of Mr. Setalvad that the Tribunal had no jurisdiction to consider the quantum of transport allowance to be paid to the workmen when once it has rejected the claim of the Union for provision of free transport.

issues.text: Whether it is the function or duty of an employer to provide transport facilities for its workmen to come to their place of work or to bear transport expenses

anchor.surface_text: Both the Companies opposed the demands of the workmen on the ground that it is not the function or duty of an employer to provide transport facilities for its workmen to come to their place, of work.

issues.text: Whether the Industrial Tribunal can impose new obligation on the employer in the interest of social justice and involve the parties in a new contract

anchor.surface_text: The principle that in a proper case the Industrial Tribunal can impose new obligation on the employer in the interest of social justice and can also involve the parties in a new contract has been recognised by this Court

issues.text: Whether there should be uniformity of conditions of service in comparable concerns in the industry in the region under the principle of industry-cum-region

anchor.surface_text: It should be borne in mind that the foundation of the principle of industrycum-region is that as far as possible, there should be uniformity of conditions of service in comparable concerns in the industry in the region

holdings.text: The grant of 15 paise per day as transport allowance to those employees staying five miles and beyond is justified in the circumstances of this case.

holdings.text: No enhanced rate of transport allowance; Tribunal correctly fixed at 15 paise considering financial capacity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No error in Tribunal's reasoning on capacity; rejects claim for 80 paise or Cynamid rate.

holdings.text: Awards of the Industrial Tribunal in respect of demand No. 4 in Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 and demand No. 6 in Civil Appeal No. 809 of 1968 are confirmed and both the appeals are dismissed. Civil Appeal No. 2086 of 1968 is also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept the contention of Mr. Setalvad that the Tribunal had no jurisdiction to consider the quantum of transport allowance to be paid to the workmen when once it has rejected the claim of the Union for provision of free transport.

In the result, the Awards of the Industrial Tribunal in respect of demand No. 4 in Civil Appeal No. 742 of 1968 and demand No. 6 in Civil Appeal No. 809 of 1968 are confirmed and both the appeals are dismissed. Civil Appeal No. 2086
